title: Preference - Bookkeeping
body: Bookkeeping preferences include settings for managing and setting up accounting. The first steps in setting up accounting are to 1) create bookkeeping accounts in the system through the Account set preferences and 2) create appropriate posting rules in the Posting rule preferences.

title: Preference - Bookkeeping
body: Changes in bookkeeping preferences are tracked:

title: Preference - Bookkeeping
body: Changes in account sets and posting rules are recorded in FA audit logs available in the FA Admin Console: FA audit logs.

title: Preference - Bookkeeping
body: Changes in posting rules are recorded in versions of each posting rule: Track data modifications through versions.

title: Account set
body: Account set

title: Account set
body: In the Account set preferences, you can define the account sets to be used when defining posting rules. An account set can constitute multiple accounts, with an account name and number defined.

title: Account set
body: An account set consists of a name and individual accounts added to the set - the individual accounts added to the account set are defined with an account number and an account name.

title: Account set
body: You can add the accounts to the set manually one by one, or modify and copy them in a text format through the Import/Export functionality available in the window.

title: Account set
body: In addition to defining the account names and numbers manually, the individual account information (name or/and number) can also be fetched dynamically from the reported transaction's security or portfolio's account information:

title: Account set
body: Typing SEC into the account number uses the transaction's security name as the account name and the transaction's security trade code as the account number.

title: Account set
body: Typing ACC into the account number uses the transaction's portfolio's secondary account number as the account code, or if not defined, the currency trade code of the portfolio account as the account code.

title: General
body: In the General preferences, you can define the logic used to create bookkeeping postings from transactions. The following table lists the configurations available:

title: Posting rule
body: Posting rule

title: Posting rule
body: In the Posting rule preferences, you can define different rules that affect the formation of the bookkeeping report or the generation of postings (if bookkeeping is enabled). These rules describe, which transactions, linked to a security with certain characteristics, are recorded to the debit and credit sides of the chosen bookkeeping account.

title: Posting rule
body: A posting rule consists of a name, a code, and a link to a defined account set. The link to an account set defines the accounts available for defining the posting rules: only the accounts defined for the linked account set are available.

title: Posting rule
body: In addition to the basic information, a posting rule consists of multiple precise rules, which are defined against a certain bookkeeping account: the whole posting rule is a combination of several, individual rules, each representing an entry in bookkeeping. A new individual rule to the posting rule is added with the Add button at the bottom of the window.

title: Posting rule
body: When posting-based bookkeeping is enabled, you can see an extended set of selectable rules and charge types compared to the available fields in standard bookkeeping. When bookkeeping is not enabled, you can only see the standard options. In addition, you can search for posting rules by filtering a posting rule set with the content of the available columns.

title: Posting rule
body: An individual rule is defined as a combination of a certain transaction type, security's characteristics, account from the chosen account set, and decision of debit/credit:

title: Posting rule
body: Transaction type*

title: Posting rule
body: Choose the transaction type of the posting rule, e.g. which types of transaction the individual rule is applied to.

title: Posting rule
body: Security

title: Posting rule
body: Choose the characteristics of the securities to apply the rule to. You can choose from:

title: Posting rule
body: Security base type, Security type, Security subtype, or individual Security. You can select only one of these properties.

title: Posting rule
body: Country, Marketplace, Class (1 through 5), or Issuer. You can select one or more of these properties.

title: Posting rule
body: If you have multiple rules, specific rules are applied over more generic ones. The security characteristics are taken into account in bottom-up order. For example, if you have separate rules for security country "Finland" and security type "Stock", the rule based on the security country is applied for your Finnish stocks (the country is below the security type in the list).

title: Posting rule
body: Account*

title: Posting rule
body: Choose the bookkeeping account the entry is recorded to from the account set linked to the posting rule (the accounts are defined in the Account set preferences for the linked account set)

title: Posting rule
body: Value

title: Posting rule
body: Leave empty, or choose from positive or negative. For each individual rule, you can define that the individual rule is executed and a posting is generated only if the value of the rule will be positive or negative. You can thus define that even if other rule criteria are met, only execute the individual rule if the positive/negative value criteria are met.

title: Posting rule
body: Charge type

title: Posting rule
body: Choose the charge type(s) of the rule by choosing them from the check boxes next to the type (the types available are described in the table below). Checking a charge type also allows you to combine different values by adding or subtracting them: when checking multiple types, these values are added up, and the + and - signs above the check boxes determine whether the checked value is taken into the calculation as positive or negative, e.g. added or subtracted in the calculation.

title: Posting rule
body: Posting date

title: Posting rule
body: Choose from Transaction date or Settlement date. Decides whether the posting date of the created posting is set based on the transaction date or settlement date of the transaction the posting is created through.

title: Posting rule
body: Payment*

title: Posting rule
body: Choose from debit or credit. Determines whether the individual rule will be recorded to the debit or credit side.

title: Posting rule
body: A new individual rule is added to the posting rule or the changes made to the rule are saved with the + button, after which the rule is shown in the rule table below the posting rule basic information.

title: Posting rule
body: The individual rules within an entire posting rule are shown in the table, grouped under the rule-defining conditions of transaction type + security's chosen characteristic. If an individual rule is changed, it is then re-grouped if necessary - you can always see an up-to-date grouping of your individual posting rules.

title: Posting rule
body: The posting rule table allows you to see all the individual rules with a quick glance, and the information of the rules is divided into columns.

title: Posting rule
body: Name

title: Posting rule
body: The name represents the name of the posting rule group, e.g. the combination of transaction type and selected security characteristics that define when the individual rules within the group are applied. The group name is shown as "Transaction type name + Security character + Second security character", e.g. "Buy + Stock" or "Sell + Stock + Finland".

title: Posting rule
body: Account

title: Posting rule
body: Shows the selected account of the individual rule

title: Posting rule
body: Posting date

title: Posting rule
body: Shows the selection for the posting date for the individual rule

title: Posting rule
body: Credit/Debit

title: Posting rule
body: Shows the selection for the debit/credit for the individual rule

title: Posting rule
body: Charge type

title: Posting rule
body: Shows all the selected charge types as "Type 1 + Type 2 + Type 3". The list shows which charge types were checked for the individual rule and how, by adding or subtracting, they are calculated together.

title: Posting rule
body: To manage the posting rules more effectively, the following functions are available:

title: Posting rule
body: Duplicating an entire posting rule. To duplicate an entire posting rule set, e.g. all the individual rules defined within a posting rule set, click the Duplicate button on the left below the defined posting rule sets. A new posting rule set is created, and the code and name of the set are set with the text "-copy" at the end.

title: Posting rule
body: Duplicating a group of rules. To duplicate a group of rules, e.g. all the individual rules with the same name / the same combination of transaction type and security characteristics, right-click the posting rule group and select "Duplicate". Define the combination of transaction type and security characteristic you want the copied rules to be applied to, and new rules are created with these new selections.

title: Posting rule
body: Duplicating an individual rule. To duplicate an individual rule, right-click the individual rule and select "Duplicate". The selections of the copied rule are shown as default - define the combination of transaction type and security characteristic you want the copied rule to be applied to, and a new rule is created with these new selections.

title: Posting rule
body: Exporting posting rules in the XLS file . To export rules as an Excel file, choose the rule set, click and download the file.

title: Posting rule
body: Exporting posting rules in the CSV file. To export the rules in the CSV file that you can edit and import back in the system, choose the rule set, click Export , and download the file.

title: Posting rule
body: Importing posting rules in the CSV file. To import a CSV file with posting rules, click Add posting rule, fill in the Name, unique Code , and Account set fields, and click Import to upload the file. Note that the CSV file must contain the same account as in the selected account set.

title: Questions and answers about bookkeeping
body: I have specified posting currencies other than the portfolio currency. How are the values calculated?

title: Questions and answers about bookkeeping
body: Postings in the security currency use the transaction amounts where they are available. Wherever portfolio report items are used, the report FX is used to retrieve the security currency amount. Portfolio currency values are calculated using available report FX rates. For currencies specified other than the portfolio or security currency, available market FX rates are used to FX the security currency amounts to the corresponding posting currency.

title: Questions and answers about bookkeeping
body: I have specified posting currencies other than portfolio currency. How is FX profit handled?

title: Questions and answers about bookkeeping
body: FX profit considers the profit/loss between the security and the chosen currency as if it were the portfolio currency. This profit/loss is then converted with available rates to the system relative to the chosen currency.

title: Questions and answers about bookkeeping
body: I have specified "Security types that get the purchase value from the cash purchase price of the account". What does this mean?

title: Questions and answers about bookkeeping
body: For some security types, such as cash transactions, the definition of purchase price is not well defined. This setting allows you to set the purchase price for a cash-type transaction as the average purchase price of the cash in the account against which the transaction is booked. This price is the average FX rate on your cash transactions against your portfolio currency.

title: Questions and answers about bookkeeping
body: Example: The portfolio is in EUR. You have a USD account in which you deposited 100,000 USD at the rate of 1.25 EUR/USD. This leaves you with a purchase value of 80,000 EUR and an average purchase price of 0.8 EUR per USD. Any cash transactions that have a negative cash effect on this account are now assumed to have this as a purchased price. If you sell off the 100,000 USD on the account at a rate of 1.0 EUR/USD, the sold value in the portfolio currency is 100,000 EUR. From a portfolio perspective in EUR, this is a loss of 20,000 EUR.

title: Questions and answers about bookkeeping
body: Any purchase price and profit realized on transactions with this set on the security type should also be visible in Analytics+. For example, any purchase value of future cashflows should be booked from the corresponding cashflow in/out transactions and viewable in Analytics+.

title: Questions and answers about bookkeeping
body: I have specified "Security types that get the purchase value from the cash purchase price of the account". Does this give me the true realized profit on FX spots/forwards?

title: Questions and answers about bookkeeping
body: No. The setting gives you the realized profit against the account's average purchase price of cash. A true realized profit on a FX spot or forward is compared against the spot price at settlement and what you contracted at inception. It is also compared against the spot pair in all cases, whereas the average price is compared against the account and portfolio (not necessarily the same as the spot/forward pair).

title: Related links
body: Standard bookkeeping rules in FA User guide.

title: Basic info
body: Basic info tab allows you to define basic properties of a security, such as name and code of the security. A red star indicates that a field is mandatory. Based on the selected security type (and its base type), the available fields vary slightly - some fields are only available on certain types of securities, and some types of securities have a more limited set of fields available.

title: Basic info
body: The fields available are:

title: Basic info
body: Code*. An individual code defined for the security. The security code separates the security from other securities (the system does not allow more than one security with the same security code). The code is used to identify the security and search for the security from the system. The best practice is to only use numbers and letters (a-z).

title: Basic info
body: ISIN code. The ISIN code of the security which identifies it on the market. The ISIN code, along with the trade code, is used to import transactions for a security, security prices, and in trading flows to link a security to trading connectors. To automatically fetch an update code for importing the security price, you have to specify the ISIN code of your security in the field and then click Update code 1-3 .

title: Basic info
body: Name*. Name of the security.

title: Basic info
body: Status*. Status of the security: Closed, Passive, or Active. Only active securities are shown in the Basic view, and only active securities can be chosen in the Transaction window. All securities can be searched in the Securities view.

title: Basic info
body: Type*. Type of the security. The drop-down menu shows security types defined in Preference, Securities, Security types. When changing the type of the security from a base type to another (e.g. changing a bond to be a stock) also clears the information that is not supported by the new base type (in the example above, all bond-specific information would be cleared since not supported by the base type stock). You can see the list of security types used in Standard Solution in FA User guide: Standard security types .

title: Basic info
body: Sub type. Sub type of the security. Options are defined in Preference, Securities, Security types. Only the sub types defined for the selected security type are visible in the drop-down menu.

title: Basic info
body: Base currency. Allows you to select the base currency of your currency cross. Only available for securities with the base type CURRENCY_CROSS. For example, for a currency cross EUR/USD, your base currency would be EUR. For this currency cross, enter the quote currency USD in the Currency field.

title: Basic info
body: Currency*. The currency your security is quoted in. All securities of the basic type currency are listed in the drop-down menu. You can see the list of currencies that are available in Standard Solution in FA User Guide: Currencies (ISO 4217) .

title: Basic info
body: Country. The country of the security. Options are defined in Preference, General, Countries. The country of the security affects taxation (corporate action) transactions.

title: Basic info
body: Marketplace. The market where the security is traded. Options are defined in Preference, Securities, Market place.

title: Basic info
body: Trade code. Identifier of the security in the market where you trade it. The trade code, along with the ISIN code, is used to import transactions for a security, security prices, and in trading flows to link a security to trading connectors.

title: Basic info
body: Update code 1, 2 and 3. Update codes for updating market prices for a security. The different update codes allow market prices to be imported and saved from different sources. The update code of the primary market data source should be defined in the Update code 1 field, and so forth. The imported market prices are saved in the right column in the Market data info tab, based on the update codes defined. If market prices are automatically fetched from an external market prices source, one of the update codes is reserved for the update code used by the external source. Update codes can be specified manually or fetched using the ISIN code in which case the ISIN must be defined.

title: Basic info
body: Settlement place. Settlement place of the security. Options are defined in Preference, Securities, Settlement place.

title: Basic info
body: URL and URL 2. External links. You can define, for example, links to security brochures.

title: Basic info
body: Rating. The rating of the security.

title: Basic info
body: Tenor. The tenor of your interest rate security. Tenors are used when building yield curves in Preference, Yield curves to determine the duration/maturity of the interest rate.

title: Basic info
body: Block size. The trade unit of the security. When equal to or less than one, the block size also affects the decimal places allowed for created cash transactions and trade orders. If no block size is defined, the allowed decimal places come from the security type preferences (see Preference - Securities). For example, if the block size is set to 0,01 the amount of the security in a transaction or trade order can be defined with two decimals, or if the block size is set to 1, the amount of the security in a transaction or trade order can be defined only with whole numbers.

title: Basic info
body: You can also define the decimal places to use in transactions created against a certain account. To do this, enter the number of decimals in the Portfolio window, Accounts tab. For details, see Accounts.

title: Basic info
body: Multipliers allow you to handle situations where you want to manipulate the unit prices you enter in the system:

title: Basic info
body: Multiplier (Conversion multiplier). Use multiplier to convert the price into a format that can be used for calculations within the system.

title: Basic info
body: If the security is quoted in a currency, set multiplier to 1.

title: Basic info
body: If the security is quoted in percentages, set multiplier to 100.

title: Basic info
body: Example: If the declared security price is 198.50, but the actual price for calculations should be 1.9850, set multiplier to 100. This means the system divides the price by 100 (198.50 / 100 = 1.9850) for internal calculations.

title: Basic info
body: Multiplier 2 (Display multiplier). Use multiplier 2 to convert the price into the desired display format.

title: Basic info
body: If the price is to be shown as-is, set multiplier 2 to 1.

title: Basic info
body: If the price needs to be transformed back to its original format, set multiplier 2 to 100.

title: Basic info
body: Example: If you set multiplier to 100 and multiplier 2 to 1, the price is displayed as 1.9850. If you set multiplier 2 to 100, the price is displayed as 198.50.

title: Basic info
body: Common use cases for multipliers:

title: Basic info
body: For bonds: Usually, you would set both multipliers to 100. Multiplier converts the price for calculations and multiplier 2 converts it back for display.

title: Basic info
body: For funds: If you receive prices in thousands and want to display them as ones, only set multiplier as 1000. For example: If the price is 1653 and you set multiplier to 1000, the system calculates it as 1.653 (1653 / 1000 = 1.653). You can enter prices manually "as ones" without the effect of the multiplier.

title: Basic info
body: For bonds, you usually define the multipliers as 100 and 100 - the first multiplier divides the price you receive to use it in calculations (e.g. 198,50 / 100 = 1,9850), and the second multiplier multiplies the value back to show it correctly to the user (e.g. 1,9850 * 100 = 198,50). For some funds, you might want to define only the first multiplier as 1000, if you receive your prices as thousands but want to show them as you use them i.e. as ones, to you user (e.g. 1 653 / 1 000 = 1,653). If you define only the first multiplier, close prices you receive on your security are divided with it, but you can still enter prices manually (such as unit price of a transaction, manual price of a security, etc.) "as ones" instead of "as thousands", i.e. without the first multiplier effect.

title: Basic info
body: Holiday calendar and Settlement date offset allow you to flexibly control on the security level which days are considered holidays and how many days the security takes to settle. Holiday calendar and settlement date offset are used for accrued interest and coupon calculations for bonds and for calculating the settlement date for trades in the security, i.e. how many business days trades for the security take to settle, and which market’s holiday calendar is used to determine these business days. For example, you can configure specific securities to settle in t+2 in a certain market, while others might settle in t+3 in another market.

title: Basic info
body: Holiday calendar – A holiday calendar that is used for this security to distinguish between business days and holidays in the market the security is traded in - the alternatives allow you to select any holiday calendar configured in Holiday calendar Preferences, such as a weekend calendar (for example Saturday/Sunday weekends or Friday/Saturday weekends) or a market-specific holiday calendar. You can set the default holiday calendar set for all new securities in Preference, Securities, Default holiday calendar.

title: Basic info
body: Enabled settl. date and Settl. date – The settlement date offset, or the security-specific number of days used when determining the settlement date for the security.

title: Basic info
body: Outstanding units. The number of shares outstanding. This value is used to calculate a Holding %available as a column in position listings.

title: Basic info
body: Votes per share. The number of votes this security has per share. This information is used to track the number of votes in a portfolio or in a contact's holdings and to produce reports to financial authorities in case the percentage of owned votes exceeds or goes below certain limits.

title: Basic info
body: Issuer. The issuer of the security. Issuers are defined in the system as contacts with the type Issuer.

title: Basic info
body: Issuer description. The security issuer description.

title: Basic info
body: Linked portfolio. The portfolio the security is based on. The linked portfolio is chosen from alternatives containing all the portfolios saved in the system. For example, funds and structured products are often based on a portfolio containing multiple different securities.

title: Basic info
body: Linked security. Another security linked to your security. For example, you can link the underlying stock to your equity option, or link the underlying instrument to a derivative.

title: Basic info
body: Manipulation. The manipulation of security prices: Direct (default, the prices are used directly as they are shown), Invert (the prices are shown as inverted) or In its own currency (the prices are shown without a currency conversion). The manipulation describes how security purchase and market unit prices are shown - usually prices are shown as "direct" (i.e. as they are used). The other options allow you for example to show FX rates as "invert" (i.e. inverted in relation to how they are used in calculations) or foreign-currency bonds "in their own currency" (i.e. even though the market value of your position is calculated in portfolio currency, the unit prices are shown without a currency conversion, allowing you to see the bond unit price directly as "percentage of the issue price").

title: Basic info
body: Price from security. The security from which this security gets the market data information. If a security is chosen, the market data information shown for this security is fetched from the chosen security's market data information - changes to the market data are done through the linked security. The market data is fetched from the linked security without the manipulation effect, or always as "Direct".

title: Basic info
body: Class 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5. Classes for the security. Class options are defined in Preference, Securities, Class 1-5. The classification system of securities can be defined as needed, and the classification system may consist of three parts: one class can be chosen for the security from each of the three available classes.

title: Basic info
body: Tags. Choose tags from the alternatives defined in Preferences - General - Tags. Tags can be defined in three different ways:

title: Basic info
body: Grouped tags (select one): you can select one tag from each tag group, grouped in separate dropdowns. Only one tag in each tag group can be chosen. To group tags in a dropdown, defined them with a hyphen as "group - tag".

title: Basic info
body: Grouped tags (select multiple): you can select multiple tags from each tag group, grouped as separate sets of checkboxes. You can check multiple tags within each tag group. To group tags as a set of checkboxes, defined them with a colon as "group : tag".

title: Basic info
body: Individual tags: search for individual tags by typing the tag in the field and choosing the correct tag from the list below the field - all available tags are shown from the downward arrow on the keyboard. You can select multiple individual tags.

title: Fund wizard
body: The Fund wizard lets you set up a fund or edit settings for an existing fund in FA Fund Management app. When you set up a fund in the FA Fund management app, FA creates a fund portfolio with the specified properties in FA Back to store the fund information and manage fund investments.

title: Fund wizard
body: To set up a new fund, click the Add fund button at the top-right of the NAV status view. To view and edit the settings of an existing fund, click the Edit fund button in the Fund details pane.

title: Fund wizard
body: The Fund wizard fields are described below.

title: Basic info tab
body: The Basic info tab contains the basic information about the fund.

title: Basic info tab
body: Fund company*

title: Basic info tab
body: The company the fund is administered by. See Create a fund company.

title: Basic info tab
body: Language*

title: Basic info tab
body: The language to use in fund portfolio reports. You can also see the language of the fund in the contact of the company in FA Back.

title: Basic info tab
body: Juridical*

title: Basic info tab
body: Juridical form of the fund company. You can also see the juridical form in the contact of the company in FA Back.

title: Basic info tab
body: Name*

title: Basic info tab
body: Fund name.

title: Basic info tab
body: Fund business ID

title: Basic info tab
body: The ID provided by the authorities for your fund. Fund business ID is used for tax reporting purposes. The ID is saved in FA Back. You can find it in the Portfolio window, IDs tab.

title: Basic info tab
body: Inception date

title: Basic info tab
body: The date when the fund starts.

title: Basic info tab
body: ID*

title: Basic info tab
body: A unique fund ID used to identify the fund and search for funds. You should only use numbers and letters (a-z).

title: Basic info tab
body: Currency*

title: Basic info tab
body: Fund currency. Once you create a fund, the currency can't be changed.

title: Basic info tab
body: Valuation method*

title: Basic info tab
body: Valuation method for the fund portfolio:

title: Basic info tab
body: Average price

title: Basic info tab
body: Average price with adjustments – Uses transaction types that control the market value of the positions with the transaction's trade amount, such as Private Equity transaction types.

title: Basic info tab
body: Average price with separate items – Valuates portfolio with average price, but keeps track of original purchase dates.

title: Basic info tab
body: FIFO

title: Basic info tab
body: FIFO (combined) – Valuates the portfolio based directly on transactions in the subportfolios.

title: Basic info tab
body: FIFO with adjustments – Uses transaction types that control the market value of the positions with the transaction's trade amount, such as Private Equity transaction types.

title: Basic info tab
body: Type*

title: Basic info tab
body: Portfolio type. Choose the type that corresponds to the fund portfolio.

title: Cash accounts
body: Cash accounts for the fund.

title: Cash accounts
body: Name*

title: Cash accounts
body: Account name.

title: Cash accounts
body: Currency*

title: Cash accounts
body: Account currency.

title: Cash accounts
body: Account number*

title: Cash accounts
body: The account number, for example, the bank account number.

title: Cash accounts
body: Set as default account

title: Cash accounts
body: Set the account as the default account of the portfolio. All transactions are by default created against this account.

title: Cash accounts
body: Shared to all parent portfolio's subportfolios

title: Cash accounts
body: Make the account available in the parent portfolio and in the other portfolios under the parent portfolio. Choose this option, for example, if you are going to use FX-hedged share classes in your fund. For details, see Hedge currency exposure.

title: Schedules tab
body: The Schedules tab contains schedule settings for calculating NAV, fees, and unofficial NAV for the fund. Schedules let you track your fund's status. For example, you can see if NAV or fees have to be calculated today. You need to fill in the dates only once. After that, dates are updated every time you accept the calculation.

title: Schedules tab
body: The Schedules tab features settings for different workflows. You can set a schedule to calculate:

title: Schedules tab
body: NAV and fees as a part of regular NAV calculation workflow.

title: Schedules tab
body: Fees, in addition to the regular NAV calculation schedule, between the regular NAV calculation dates (to set a schedule for this workflow, click Add separate fee calculation schedule).

title: Schedules tab
body: Performance fee with equalization method (to set a schedule for performance fee equalization, click Add fee crystallization schedule). You can also use the same schedule for fee capitalization if you have chosen it in fee settings on the Fee structure tab.

title: Schedules tab
body: Unofficial NAV for reporting purposes between the scheduled regular NAV calculations (to set a schedule for this workflow, click Add unofficial NAV calculation schedule).

title: Schedules tab
body: To learn more about calculation workflows, see Workflows and NAV statuses.

title: Schedules tab
body: Frequency

title: Schedules tab
body: Calculation frequency: daily, weekly, every two weeks, and so on.

title: Schedules tab
body: If you want to make calculations without a preset schedule, choose "No schedule" and select Allow non-scheduled calculations below. This option is available for NAV, fees, and unofficial NAV calculations.

title: Schedules tab
body: Holiday calendar

title: Schedules tab
body: The holiday calendar to take into account in the calculation schedule. If you don't find a suitable holiday calendar from the list, you can create a calendar in FA Back (for details, see Preference - Securities in the FA Back reference).

title: Schedules tab
body: Roll convention

title: Schedules tab
body: Calculation schedule based on the day of the month or day of the week. One of the most common roll conventions is "EOM" (end-of-month).

title: Schedules tab
body: You set the calculation frequency to "Every three months" and the first calculation date is on June 30th. The calculation dates will fall on the 30th of each month (September 30th, December 30th, March 30th, and so on). For months with 31 days, the calculation date won't be the last day of the month. If you choose the "End of Month (EOM)" roll convention, the system will recognize that June 30th is the last day of the month, and the calculation dates will fall on the last day of each month (September 30th, December 31st, March 31st, and so on).

title: Schedules tab
body: Business day convention

title: Schedules tab
body: Business day convention determines how to adjust a date if it falls on a non-business day.

title: Schedules tab
body: First date

title: Schedules tab
body: The date for which the calculation is made for the first time.

title: Schedules tab
body: Previous date

title: Schedules tab
body: The date for which the latest NAV or fees were calculated. For the newly created fund, previous NAV date must be the same as the first NAV date.

title: Schedules tab
body: Calculation delay in days

title: Schedules tab
body: The number of days between the NAV or fees date and the calculation date. Enter "0" to calculate NAV or fees on the same date, or choose the number of days to calculate NAV or fees with a delay.

title: Schedules tab
body: Calculate next days

title: Schedules tab
body: The button sets the next NAV or fees date and calculation dates according to the information entered above.

title: Schedules tab
body: Next NAV date

title: Schedules tab
body: The next NAV or fees date based on the frequency, holiday calendar conventions and the first NAV or fees date chosen above.

title: Schedules tab
body: Previous calculation date

title: Schedules tab
body: Previous calculation date based on the previous NAV or fees date and calculation delay.

title: Schedules tab
body: Next calculation date

title: Schedules tab
body: Next calculation date based on the next NAV or fees date and calculation delay.

title: Schedules tab
body: Allow non-scheduled calculations

title: Schedules tab
body: Allows starting a calculation outside the schedule, when the fund has "No action" status. For example, this can be useful in case you don't calculate scheduled NAV often but there are big movements in fund’s capital that affect the valuation of the fund. The Allow non-scheduled calculations option is available for NAV, fees, and unofficial NAV calculations.

title: Schedules tab
body: Non-scheduled NAV calculation result is shown in the NAV window. The calculation date is shown in the Latest NAV column in the NAV status view.

title: Fee structure tab
body: The Fee structure tab lets you set or edit the fees applied to the whole fund. Fund-level fees are calculated first, in the order you place them in the Fund wizard, followed by the share class fees.

title: Fee structure tab
body: To add fees per share class, use the Share class wizard.

title: Fund fees
body: The Fund fees section lists the fund fees. To add a fee formula, click the Add fee button at the top-right.

title: Fund fees
body: Fee formula

title: Fund fees
body: Fee formula used to calculate the fee and generate fee transaction.

title: Fund fees
body: Fee transaction type

title: Fund fees
body: Transaction type linked to the chosen fee formula.

title: Fund fees
body: Amount or %

title: Fund fees
body: Fee percentage or amount in the fund currency, depending on the fee formula.

title: Fund fees
body: Decimals

title: Fund fees
body: The number of decimals used for calculating fees (0 to 10). The "Default" value is 2 decimals.

title: Fund fees
body: Ex-post cost category

title: Fund fees
body: Ex-post cost category for the fee. The categorization is used in cost analysis and reporting (see View ex-post costs and charges in FA User guide), as well as for creating kickbacks (see Rebate contracts (kickbacks) in FA User guide).

title: Fund fees
body: Additional options

title: Fund fees
body: Additional fee setups.

title: Fund fees
body: Calculate fee per security

title: Fund fees
body: Run the formula multiple times, for each security in the fund investment portfolio. Used, for example, for kickbacks.

title: Fund fees
body: Formula sets its own account

title: Fund fees
body: Create an account for the fee formula. For example, it can be useful with accrued account interest transactions over multiple accounts.

title: Fund fees
body: Include in income distribution

title: Fund fees
body: Include the fee in the income distribution calculation.

title: Fund fees
body: Use crystallization schedule for capitalization

title: Fund fees
body: Capitalize fees automatically on the crystallization date when you accept NAV. The crystallization dates are defined in the Fund wizard, Schedules tab. Fees are capitalized to the account that has the “Fee capitalization” tag. If no account is marked with this tag, fees are capitalized to the default cash account.

title: Alternative fee calculation modes
body: The Alternative fee calculation modes section contains advanced settings that affect fee handling in the NAV calculation. Leave the selections unticked for regular fee handling.

title: Alternative fee calculation modes
body: Include fees calculated since the previous NAV calculation date in the current NAV calculation (if fees are calculated separately from NAV)

title: Alternative fee calculation modes
body: Take the fees calculated since previous NAV calculation into account when calculating the current NAV.

title: Alternative fee calculation modes
body: Allocate fees per share class from the beginning of the fund (for example, for private equity funds)

title: Alternative fee calculation modes
body: Calculate fees per share class since the beginning of the fund (not since the latest NAV calculation). To learn more, see Calculate and accept NAV.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: The Performance fee equalization section contains the fee formula to use if you calculate performance fee and equalize it regularly according to the crystallization schedule. In addition to choosing the fee formula here, you need to define the crystallization schedule in the Fund wizard, Schedules tab, and the fee parameters in the Share class wizard, Fee structure tab.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Select Calculate performance equalization fee with contingent redemption method and fill in the fields to define the fee settings:

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Fee formula

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Fee formula used to calculate performance fee transactions: choose "Performance fee with crystallization".

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Fee transaction type

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Transaction type linked to the chosen performance fee formula.

title: Fund reporting tab
body: The Fund reporting tab lets you define the settings to produce fund reporting data, including fund KPIs, and store it in the FA Fund Management app (see Fund reporting view for details). Click Enable fund reporting and fill in the fields.

title: Fund reporting tab
body: Reporting schedule

title: Fund reporting tab
body: The settings for the fund reporting schedule are similar to NAV and fee calculation schedules (see Schedules tab).

title: Fund reporting tab
body: Allocation groups

title: Fund reporting tab
body: Allocation groups to analyze the fund portfolio contents. To learn more about allocations, see Allocation in the FA Back reference.

title: Order execution tab
body: The Order execution tab lets you define and edit the automatic trade order execution settings.

title: Order execution tab
body: Cut-off time

title: Order execution tab
body: The cut-off time for the fund in 24 h format, for example, “13:00”. After you set the cut-off time, use decision tables make sure that certain transactions or trade orders that come after the cut-off time don't affect the NAV calculation. To learn more, see Set the cut-off time in FA User guide.

title: Order execution tab
body: Enable automatic order execution

title: Order execution tab
body: Enable automatic order execution and create transactions for the fund when NAV is accepted.

title: Order execution tab
body: Default transaction types

title: Order execution tab
body: Transaction types for the cash transactions (unit holder deposits and withdrawals).

title: Order execution tab
body: Account for cash transactions

title: Order execution tab
body: Account number for the cash transactions. Leave the field empty to use the default account.

title: Order execution tab
body: Transaction types for bookkeeping

title: Order execution tab
body: For bookkeeping purposes, you can provide transaction types that are used when creating cash transaction for client orders whose settlement date doesn’t follow the default logic.

title: Order execution tab
body: Leave these transaction types empty to use the accounts for cash transactions instead.

title: Client orders
body: Settlement cycle

title: Client orders
body: Setting to define the settlement date for subscriptions and redemptions if it is missing in the client order. Enter the number of days after the transaction date.

title: Client orders
body: Account for client transactions

title: Client orders
body: Account used for client transactions created from trade orders.

title: Client orders
body: Use the account of the trade order to transactions

title: Client orders
body: Use the currency account (or default account) to transactions

title: Client orders
body: Use the default account to transactions

title: Cash transactions created for the fund
body: Default transaction types

title: Cash transactions created for the fund
body: Transaction types for the cash transactions (unit holder deposits and withdrawals). We recommend using the "Deposit - Fund (FMDEP)" and "Withdrawal - Fund (FMWD)" types.

title: Cash transactions created for the fund
body: Account for cash transactions

title: Cash transactions created for the fund
body: Account number for the cash transactions. Leave the field empty to use the default account.

title: Cash transactions created for the fund
body: Transaction types for bookkeeping

title: Cash transactions created for the fund
body: For bookkeeping purposes, you can provide transaction types that are used when creating cash transaction for client orders whose settlement date doesn’t follow the default logic.

title: Cash transactions created for the fund
body: Leave these transaction types empty to use the accounts for cash transactions instead.

title: Breakdown of cash transactions
body: Breakdown of trade amount in cash transactions.

title: Breakdown of cash transactions
body: Par value (the first NAV value)

title: Breakdown of cash transactions
body: Par value to use in the deposit and withdrawal transactions.

title: Breakdown of cash transactions
body: Par value cost type

title: Breakdown of cash transactions
body: Income distribution tax type

title: Breakdown of cash transactions
body: Over/ under value cost type

title: Breakdown of cash transactions
body: Swing tax type

title: Breakdown of cash transactions
body: Cost and tax types to record in the deposit and withdrawal transactions.

title: NAV reporting tab
body: The NAV reporting tab features options for setting up custom NAV reports and sending NAV reports by email.

title: NAV reporting tab
body: NAV report PDF template

title: NAV reporting tab
body: The path to the PDF template used for building NAV reports. The path to the default template is pre-filled for you. To use a custom template, enter the template path in the field. To learn more about configuring custom reports, see Customize the NAV report (XLSX) in FA Developer guide.

title: NAV reporting tab
body: NAV report XLSX template

title: NAV reporting tab
body: The path to the XSLX template used for building NAV reports. The path to the default template is pre-filled for you. To use a custom template, enter the template path in the field. To learn more about configuring custom reports, see Customize the NAV report (XLSX) in FA Developer guide.

title: NAV reporting tab
body: Send report via email

title: NAV reporting tab
body: Enable sending NAV reports by email. You can send NAV reports by email from FA Back (for instructions, see Send documents via email). We recommend that your administrator schedules the report sending in Tools → Administer → Scheduled functions in FA Back. For example, you can have the emails sent out every afternoon on the days when you calculate NAV.

title: NAV reporting tab
body: Recipients

title: NAV reporting tab
body: Emails to send the reports to. Email addresses in this field are automatically added to the "Report via email" list of emails in FA Back, meaning that all other reports that are generated for the fund are sent to this email too.

title: Swing pricing tab
body: The Swing pricing tab lets you define settings for swing pricing. Click Apply swing pricing and fill in the fields.

title: Swing pricing tab
body: Official NAV

title: Swing pricing tab
body: A setting to choose how swing adjustment is used in your fund. Choose one of the options:

title: Swing pricing tab
body: Swung NAV - Swing adjustment is included in official NAV. The logic of handling swing adjustment is shown in the table.

title: Swing pricing tab
body: Unswung NAV – Swing adjustment is not included in official NAV. The logic of handling swing adjustment is shown in the table.

title: Swing factor
body: Swing factor is used for adjusting the unit price.

title: Swing factor
body: For swinging up

title: Swing factor
body: The percentage to adjust the unit price if the net inflow of the fund exceeds the threshold.

title: Swing factor
body: For swinging down

title: Swing factor
body: The percentage to adjust the unit price if the net outflow of the fund exceeds the threshold.

title: Thresholds
body: Swing thresholds are the net inflow or net outflow of the fund that triggers the adjustment to the NAV. You can set a threshold in fund currency or as a percentage of the fund's total net asset value on the NAV date.

title: Thresholds
body: For swinging up

title: Thresholds
body: Net inflow that triggers swinging up.

title: Thresholds
body: For swinging down

title: Thresholds
body: Net outflow that triggers swinging down.

title: Income distribution tab
body: The Income distribution tab features settings for keeping track of the fund's accrued income and calculating the tax on it if needed. FA Fund Management app calculates the accrued income based on the bookkeeping postings and records the result into your fund every time you calculate NAV. You can choose to calculate tax on the accrued income at the same time.

title: Income distribution tab
body: After NAV is calculated, the system creates transactions for accrued income and calculated tax. The calculation also allocates accrued income per share class in security market data (Security window, Market data tab in FA Back) while pricing the share classes with NAV.

title: Income distribution tab
body: Click Enable income distribution and fill in the fields.

title: Accrued income
body: Settings to calculate accrued income.

title: Accrued income
body: Accrued income formula

title: Accrued income
body: Fee formula to calculate accrued income. Accrued income is calculated every time you calculate NAV.

title: Accrued income
body: Fee formula can be specified either for the whole fund or for a share class (not for both). Make sure that you don’t have any fee formulas in the Share class wizard, Fee structure tab if you use fund-level rules and the other way round.

title: Accrued income
body: Transaction type

title: Accrued income
body: Type of the transaction generated by the accrued income formula.

title: Accrued income
body: Bookkeeping accounts used to calculate income distributions

title: Accrued income
body: Fields for bookkeeping accounts to track accrued income. When you calculate NAV, FA sums up the balances on the specified bookkeeping accounts on the NAV date. To enter multiple account numbers, separate them with a semicolon. To include only part of the account balance in the calculation, enter a percentage after the account number. For example, "123456=45,5" means that 45,5% of the 123456 account balance is used in the calculation.

title: Accrued income
body: Mark all “Ready” bookkeeping postings from start of the year to the NAV date as “Reported” when NAV is accepted

title: Accrued income
body: Change the status of bookkeeping postings produced by income distribution when the NAV is accepted. In most cases, you need to have this option selected.

title: Accrued tax
body: Settings to calculate tax on accrued income.

title: Accrued tax
body: Calculate tax of the accrued income distribution

title: Accrued tax
body: Option to record tax to be paid on the accrued income. Fill in the tax parameters below.

title: Accrued tax
body: Tax formula

title: Accrued tax
body: Fee formula used to calculate tax on accrued income.

title: Accrued tax
body: Transaction type

title: Accrued tax
body: Type of the transaction generated by the tax formula.

title: Accrued tax
body: Tax percentage

title: Accrued tax
body: Percentage of accrued income to be paid as tax.

title: Accounting tab
body: The Accounting tab lets you define accounts and rules for generating postings for income distribution (for other income distribution settings, see Income distribution tab .

title: Accounting tab
body: Automated deferral runs before NAV calculation

title: Accounting tab
body: Settings for deferral runs before NAV calculation. You need to run deferrals to generate postings for the income distribution calculation.

title: Accounting tab
body: Choose the deferral type to run and the previous deferral date. If the previous deferral date is empty, the starting date of the fund is used.

title: Accounting tab
body: Accounting rules for income distribution-related postings

title: Accounting tab
body: Accounting rules that are used to generate postings related to income distribution. These rules are specified in the system configuration made by FA consultants. Enter them in the Accounting rules for income distribution-related postings field to change posting status to “Reported” when you accept NAV.

title: Advanced settings tab
body: The Advanced settings tab contains miscellaneous settings for your fund.

title: Unit certificates
body: Setting for unit certificates. To learn more about unit certificates in the FA Fund management app, see the Unit certificate

title: Unit certificates
body: Report template (PDF)

title: Unit certificates
body: The path to the custom Unit certificate template. For example, "/UnitCertificateCustom/Unit certificate".

title: Unit certificates
body: Transaction types

title: Unit certificates
body: Transaction types for the unit certificate to show in the Shareholder registry view. If empty, only the UC type is shown.

title: Pricing of share class without shareholders
body: Define how the unit price for newly created share classes with no shareholders is set:

title: Pricing of share class without shareholders
body: Select the checkbox to use the previous price of the share class.

title: Pricing of share class without shareholders
body: Leave the checkbox empty to use the price from the share class with a higher priority.

title: Allocation
body: Define the setting for updating the share class security allocations.

title: Allocation
body: Update fund security allocations automatically when accepting NAV

title: Allocation
body: The option to update allocations for the share class securities when you accept NAV. You can view allocations in the Security window, Allocations tab in FA Back.

title: Allocation
body: Update allocations for securities that get price from share classes

title: Allocation
body: The option to update allocations for securities that get prices from share classes. For example, such structure with multiple securities can be used, if your fund shares are sold via a nominee. In this case, the share class ownership is handled with two securities:

title: Allocation
body: Share class security that is automatically created in FA Back when you add a share class. This security has the nominee as a shareholder.

title: Allocation
body: Security that has the same prices as the share class security and is owned by end clients. This security is used to get share class positions in clients' portfolios. To link this security to the share class security, open it in FA Back and choose the share class security in the Price from security field.

title: Allocation
body: Choose Update allocations for all securities that get price from share classes to have allocations updated for all securities.

title: Allocation
body: Allocation groups

title: Allocation
body: Allocation groups to update share class allocations based on fund portfolio contents when you accept NAV. Allocations are updated for the configured group(s), based on the fund portfolio’s allocations on the NAV date.

title: Share class wizard
body: The Share class wizard lets you create, edit or delete a fund share class. When you create a share class in the Fund management app, FA creates a share class security with the specified properties in FA Back.

title: Share class wizard
body: To add a share class, click the button in the Fund details pane.

title: Share class wizard
body: To edit a share class, click the button in the Share class details pane.

title: Share class wizard
body: To delete a share class click Delete in the Share class wizard. You can delete a share class only if it doesn't have any transactions and isn't used in benchmarks.

title: Basic info tab
body: Share class details and NAV calculation settings.

title: Basic info tab
body: Code*

title: Basic info tab
body: A unique code defined for the share class. The code is used to identify the share class security and search for securities in the system. We recommend using numbers and letters (a-z) and avoiding special characters in the security code.

title: Basic info tab
body: ISIN

title: Basic info tab
body: The ISIN code of the share class security.

title: Basic info tab
body: Name*

title: Basic info tab
body: Name of the share class security.

title: Basic info tab
body: Type*

title: Basic info tab
body: Share class security type. Choose the type that is configured for funds in Preferences. If you have standard solution configuration, use Collective investment vehicles type.

title: Basic info tab
body: Holiday calendar*

title: Basic info tab
body: A holiday calendar that determines business days and holidays in the market to set a settlement date for subscriptions and redemptions. Holiday calendar options are configured in Preferences. You can also set the default holiday calendar used for new securities in Preferences.

title: Basic info tab
body: Share class priority

title: Basic info tab
body: The order in which share class NAVs are calculated if there are multiple share classes. The NAV for the share class with the highest priority is calculated first.

title: Basic info tab
body: Decimal count for transaction units

title: Basic info tab
body: Number of decimals used in the units field of the client transactions. If the field is empty, the number of decimals set for the security type is used.

title: Pricing tab
body: Unit price settings:

title: Pricing tab
body: Currency

title: Pricing tab
body: Share class currency – the currency share class units are quoted in.

title: Pricing tab
body: Initial price

title: Pricing tab
body: (Set for a new share class). Initial price of the share class unit. Initial unit price is used for the first NAV calculation. The price you enter is copied to the Market data info tab in the Security window in FA Back.

title: Pricing tab
body: Date of initial price

title: Pricing tab
body: (Set when you create a share class). The date for which the initial unit price is valid.

title: Pricing tab
body: Format

title: Pricing tab
body: Unit price multipliers to use in calculations. For more information about multipliers, see the description of the Basic info tab in the Security window. Choose one of the options:

title: Pricing tab
body: Show price as is – Show the share class unit price without any multipliers.

title: Pricing tab
body: In percentage – Use "100" in both Multiplier fields for the security.

title: Pricing tab
body: Add manually – Enter the multipliers in the fields below.

title: Pricing tab
body: Decimals for share class NAV

title: Pricing tab
body: The number of decimals used in the share class NAV. If the field is empty, NAV is stored with 10 decimals.

title: Pricing tab
body: Dividend payments

title: Pricing tab
body: Enable dividend payments for the share class. You can calculate and execute dividends in the Dividends view. For details, see Dividends view.

title: Fee structure tab
body: The Fee structure tab defines costs and fees applied on the share class level. Share class-level fees are calculated after the fund level fees, in the order you put them in the Share class wizard. Click Add fee and enter the information about the share class fees:

title: Fund fees
body: Fund fees

title: Fund fees
body: Fee formula

title: Fund fees
body: Fee formula used to calculate the fee and generate fee transaction.

title: Fund fees
body: Fee transaction type

title: Fund fees
body: Transaction type linked to the chosen fee formula.

title: Fund fees
body: Amount or %

title: Fund fees
body: Fee percentage or amount in the fund currency, depending on the fee formula.

title: Fund fees
body: Decimals

title: Fund fees
body: The number of decimals used for calculating fees (0 to 10). The “Default” value is 2 decimals.

title: Fund fees
body: Ex-post cost category

title: Fund fees
body: Ex-post cost category for the fee. The categorization is used in cost analysis and reporting (see View ex-post costs and charges in FA User guide), as well as for creating kickbacks (see Rebate contracts (kickbacks) in FA User guide).

title: Fund fees
body: Account currency

title: Fund fees
body: The currency of the share class fee accrual account. Choose if the fees should be accrued in the fund currency or in the share class currency. The field is shown only if the share class currency is different from the fund currency.

title: Fund fees
body: Additional options

title: Fund fees
body: Additional fee setups.

title: Fund fees
body: Formula sets its own account

title: Fund fees
body: Set an account for the fee formula. For example, this can be useful with accrued account interest transactions over multiple accounts.

title: Fund fees
body: Include in income distribution

title: Fund fees
body: Include the fee in the income distribution calculation.

title: Fund fees
body: Use crystallization schedule for capitalization

title: Fund fees
body: Capitalize fees automatically on the crystallization date when you accept NAV. The crystallization dates are defined in the Fund wizard, Schedules tab. Fees are capitalized to the account that has “Fee capitalization” tag. If no account is marked with this tag, fees are capitalized to the default cash account.

title: Transaction fees
body: The Transaction fees section contains parameters for subscription and redemption fees and charging them automatically when you calculate NAV. Enter the subscription and redemption fee parameters:

title: Transaction fees
body: Calculate fee for net trade amount-based subscriptions

title: Transaction fees
body: The amount from which the subscription fee is calculated in net trade amount-based trade orders: order trade amount or the sum invested in the fund.

title: Transaction fees
body: Define default transaction fees

title: Transaction fees
body: Settings for subscription and redemption fees calculated automatically and included in the transaction:

title: Transaction fees
body: Cost percentage

title: Transaction fees
body: Fee percentage to calculate the fee amount.

title: Transaction fees
body: To set the fee as a fixed amount per transaction, enter "0" as a cost percentage and then specify the fee amount in the Minimum field.

title: Transaction fees
body: Minimum

title: Transaction fees
body: The minimum fee amount to charge.

title: Transaction fees
body: Currency

title: Transaction fees
body: Fee currency automatically set to the share class currency.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: The Performance fee equalization section contains parameters to calculate and equalize performance fee. In addition to choosing the fee parameters here, you need to define the crystallization schedule in the Fund wizard, Schedules tab, and the fee formula in the Fund wizard, Fee structure tab.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Fee percentage

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Fee percentage to calculate the fee amount.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Hurdle rate

title: Performance fee equalization
body: The minimum NAV increase above HWM starting from which the performance fee is paid.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Day count

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Day count convention to use in performance fee calculation with hurdle rate. If the calculation period is less than a year, the hurdle rate is adjusted proportionally using the day count convention you chose.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: High-water mark

title: Performance fee equalization
body: The initial high water mark (HWM) to use for the performance fee calculation. Usually, HWM is set to the highest NAV value in the share class. On the crystallization date, FA Fund Management compares the share class NAV to the HWM. If NAV is higher than HWM, the HWM value is updated to the current NAV value.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: High-water mark date

title: Performance fee equalization
body: The date on which high-water mark is set.

title: Cash transactions tab
body: Account settings to handle deposits and withdrawals.

title: Cash transactions tab
body: Account number

title: Cash transactions tab
body: A fund portfolio account to record deposits and withdrawals to. If the field is empty, the account in the fund settings or the default account is used.

title: Tax reporting tab
body: Settings for the Finnish tax reporting: fund company business ID and fund business ID.

title: FX hedging tab
body: FX hedging settings to apply if your share class currency is different from the fund currency and you want to use FX hedging to neutralize the effect of the exchange rate. Click Enable FX hedging and fill in the fields. For full instruction on how to set up and manage FX-hedged share classes, see Hedge currency exposure in FA User guide.

title: FX hedging tab
body: Formula

title: FX hedging tab
body: The formula for the FX hedge accrual. You can choose the "FX hedge formula" that comes pre-configured in Standard solution.

title: FX hedging tab
body: FX hedge transaction type

title: FX hedging tab
body: Transaction type linked to the FX hedging formula.

title: FX hedging tab
body: Hedge parent portfolio

title: FX hedging tab
body: ID and portfolio type of the hedge parent portfolio that links fund and hedge portfolios in FA Back. The hedge parent portfolio is empty. It is used to group the fund and hedge portfolios and share accounts between them. You can edit the hedge parent portfolio properties only when you enable hedging for one of the fund share classes for the first time. After that, hedge parent portfolio is set and can't be edited.

title: FX hedging tab
body: Hedge portfolio

title: FX hedging tab
body: ID and portfolio type of the hedge portfolio that contains FX contracts in FA Back. You can edit the hedge portfolio properties only when you enable hedging for a share class. After that, the hedge portfolio is set and can't be edited.

title: View fund shareholders
body: Shareholder registry view shows the fund’s shareholders and their ownership in the fund as a tree structure. Expand the shareholder name to view share classes to which the shareholder has ownership. Expand a share class to view the purchase lots in this share class.

title: Fund selection
body: The Select a fund dropdown at the top lets you choose a fund to view shareholders for. This dropdown shows the funds included in groups with a code starting with “FAFUND”. Learn more about setting up fund groups in FA User Guide.

title: Registry date
body: Choose the date in the Registry date field to view the fund shareholders for a specific date.

title: Load purchase lots
body: To see the purchase lots for each shareholder in the list, check the Load purchase lots box. This shows the whole history of purchase lots, including the ones not held anymore. By default, this option is disabled.

title: Table columns
body: Contact ID

title: Table columns
body: The customer’s contact ID stored in FA Back. This is a unique ID of the shareholder, such as a social security number.

title: Table columns
body: Shareholder

title: Table columns
body: The top level shows name of the shareholder. Lower levels show share classes the shareholder owns and date of the open purchase lots within each share class (the individual purchases the shareholder made into the share class). Purchase lots under each share class are ordered from oldest to newest according to FIFO (based on purchase lot date or the order they appear in during the same date).

title: Table columns
body: Address (Address 1, Address 2, Postal code, City, Country)

title: Table columns
body: The details stored in the Address info tab of the contact in FA Back. If the customer information contains multiple addresses, the shareholder registry shows the first address defined in the contact in FA Back.

title: Table columns
body: Tax country

title: Table columns
body: Classifications stored under "tax country" in the contact in FA Back. The tax country often indicates where the shareholder pays taxes. In the FA Platform, this is also used to calculate taxes.

title: Table columns
body: Share class

title: Table columns
body: The name of the share class.

title: Table columns
body: Total ownership

title: Table columns

title: Table columns
body: Unit certificates

title: Table columns
body: A unit certificate states the number of fund or share class units owned by a shareholder. It may cover all units owned by the shareholder or a part of them. A unit certificate can be used if a shareholder wants to, for example, pledge their shares as collateral for a loan.

title: Table columns
body: Units

title: Table columns
body: Shown on the share class, unit certificates, and purchase lot levels. The number of units the shareholder owns in a share class or units purchased in a specific purchase lot.

title: Table columns
body: Market value

title: Table columns
body: The market value of the position from the selected date. If the market value is not available for this date, the previous date is used.

title: Table columns
body: Purchase value

title: Table columns
body: The purchase value of the position or purchase lot in the share class currency.

title: Table columns
body: Currency

title: Table columns
body: The currency of the share class.

title: Table columns
body: Change (amount)

title: Table columns
body: The difference between the Purchase value and Market value columns in the share class currency.

title: Table columns
body: Change (%)

title: Table columns
body: The difference between the Purchase value and Market value columns as a percentage.

title: Table columns
body: Purchase lot ID

title: Table columns
body: Shown on the purchase lot level. The purchase lot ID (based on the order the purchase lots were created) or the unit certificate ID (starting with "UC").

title: Table columns
body: Purchase date

title: Table columns
body: The date the purchase lot was purchased.

title: Export button
body: You can use the Export button to generate a shareholders report as an XLSX file. To learn more about the report, see Shareholders report.

title: Shareholder details
body: The Info pane shows the shareholder's contact ID and contact details, meaning their address and the juridical form.

title: Shareholder details
body: Juridical form

title: Shareholder details
body: Classifications stored under "juridical form" in the contact in FA Back. Juridical form is often used to differentiate between private persons and companies.

title: Shareholder details
body: The Unit certificates pane shows the number of units acquired in each share class by purchase lots and the unit certificates issued for the shareholder (marked with "UC"). This pane lets you create, download and delete unit certificates. To learn more about this document, see the Unit certificate section.

title: Shareholder details
body: To generate a unit certificate, click the icon, enter the number of units and click Create. To download a previously generated unit certificate, click the PDF icon . To delete a unit certificate after it is returned, click . To learn more, see the Generating and deleting the unit certificate section.

title: View funds and share classes
body: NAV status view shows the list of your funds with key information, NAV status and dates, and outstanding trade orders.

title: View the list of funds
body: The list of funds shows your funds and their share classes in a tree structure. For the list of columns, see Fund and share class information.

title: View the list of funds
body: The Fund group dropdown at the top of the fund list lets you choose a fund group to view. This dropdown shows the fund portfolio groups that have a code starting with “FAFUND”. Learn more about setting up portfolio groups in the FA Back reference: Group view. Fund share classes are shown under each fund in the list.

title: View fund details
body: To view the fund details, click the fund in the list and open the Fund details pane on the right. You can see:

title: View fund details
body: Basic info: fund ID and fund currency.

title: View fund details
body: NAV information: NAV status, next NAV date, who and when calculated and accepted the current NAV. If the NAV acceptance is in progress, you can view the details by clicking View progress.

title: View fund details
body: Orders: outstanding trade orders per share class affecting the next NAV calculation.

title: View fund details
body: For details about each field, see Fund and share class information.

title: View fund details
body: You can open the fund portfolio in FA Back by clicking View in FA Back .

title: View share class details
body: To view the share class details, select the share class from the list and open the Share class details pane on the right. You can see:

title: View share class details
body: Basic info: share class security information (Code, ISIN code, Currency), NAV data (Latest NAV as well as the NAV history graph) and high-water mark information (if applicable).

title: View share class details
body: Orders: outstanding trade orders for the share class affecting the next NAV calculation.

title: View share class details
body: For details about each field, see Fund and share class information.

title: View share class details
body: You can open the share class security in FA Back by clicking View in FA Back .

title: Fund and share class information
body: ID

title: Fund and share class information
body: Portfolio ID for funds and Security code for share classes.

title: Fund and share class information
body: Status

title: Fund and share class information
body: NAV calculation status that indicates if you should calculate NAV for the fund today. Learn more about the statuses in the Workflows and NAV statuses section. NAV statuses are shown for the current date and time, displayed above the funds list. If the date and time aren’t current, refresh the page by clicking the refresh icon at the top-right corner to view the recent information.

title: Fund and share class information
body: Error

title: Fund and share class information
body: Errors in NAV calculation and acceptance. If there are any errors, you can see the icon next to the fund status. To view the errors, hover the mouse over the icon. To find out the error details, go to the audit log in the Fund details pane on the right.

title: Fund and share class information
body: Next NAV

title: Fund and share class information
body: The date for which you should calculate and accept NAV next. NAV date may differ from the calculation date – the date when you should do the calculation.

title: Fund and share class information
body: For example, you might calculate NAV for the last day of the month (for example, 31.1) on the first day of the next month (for example, 1.2). When you log in on 1.2 your fund status would be “pending NAV”, but the next NAV date would show 31.1.

title: Fund and share class information
